nodes.text: Major infrastructure projects systematically get the worst projects built because promoters and planners produce biased ex ante estimates (understating costs, overstating benefits), causing cost overruns, benefit shortfalls, and a 'survival of the un-fittest' outcome

Characteristics of major infrastructure projects: long planning horizons, complex interfaces, non-standard technology, multi-actor decision making, early lock-in, changing scope, and frequent unaccounted unplanned events

Empirical evidence: cost overruns are widespread in transportation projects (N=258) with average overruns: rail 44.7%, bridges/tunnels 33.8%, roads 20.4%; 9 out of 10 projects have cost overrun and overruns persist over 70 years

Empirical evidence: traffic and benefit forecast errors are large (N=208): rail passenger traffic on average 51.4% lower than forecast, road traffic errors around 9.5% on average with large variance; forecast inaccuracy constant over 30 years
Claim: Conventional ex ante cost-benefit analyses are unreliable for major infrastructure because inputs (costs, demand forecasts) are systematically biased, producing misleading project appraisals

Three explanatory types for forecasting errors: technical (honest errors), psychological (optimism bias/planning fallacy), and political-economic (strategic misrepresentation); empirical data reject technical explanations as primary

Claim supported by interviews and case studies: political-economic explanations and strategic misrepresentation best account for systematic underestimation of costs and overestimation of benefits due to incentives to gain approval and funding

Mechanism 'survival of the un-fittest': projects that look best on paper (via underestimated costs and overstated benefits) are likeliest to be funded but tend to have largest overruns and shortfalls in reality

Method: Reference class forecasting (outside view) steps: (1) identify relevant reference class of past projects, (2) establish probability distribution of outcomes for that class using empirical data, (3) position the current project in that distribution to estimate likely outcomes

Result and evidence: Reference class forecasting has been more accurate in practice (Edinburgh Tram adjustment example, official endorsements, and use in multiple countries) and can reduce optimism and strategic bias when applied

Claim: Better governance and accountability are essential where actors intentionally bias forecasts; measures include transparency, independent peer review, benchmarking, public scrutiny, professional and criminal penalties, and shifting appraisal away from promoters

Evidence: Current trends increasing systemic risk—rapid stimulus-driven spending, geographic shift to emerging economies (higher average overruns there), and rising integration of ICT into projects (which often performs worse)—increase likelihood of financial and economic disasters

Result: Combined trends create amplified, correlated risks ('risk to the third degree') making efficient project delivery especially critical and challenging during the stimulus and global investment boom

Conclusion: The cure requires combining outside-view methods (reference class forecasting) with strengthened governance and incentive structures so accurate forecasts are rewarded and deception punished
Evidence/Result: Forecast accuracy has not improved over decades despite methodological investments, contradicting the claim that errors are primarily technical or due to inexperience

Policy recommendation: Increase market accountability by requiring meaningful private finance participation (e.g., at least one-third without sovereign guarantee), make forecasters share financial responsibility, and centralize contract-writing to reduce asymmetry between clients and contractors
